title: Five cultural outings to enjoy with a baby in Paris
Migration: France agrees to return deal with UK
subhead: Paris has agreed to take back individuals who managed to cross the Channel but are not eligible for asylum in the UK. In exchange, London will accept those who qualify for asylum through a legal process. Approximately 21,000 people have reached England in small boats since the beginning of the year.
byline: By Cécile Ducourtieux (London, correspondent) and Julia Pascual

title: Dissension runs deep between Lula and Western democracies
Amnesty International condemns 'repression' of environmental and climate activists in France
subhead: In a report published on Wednesday, July 3, the NGO expressed concern about 'growing attacks' on freedoms of expression, protest and association, warning of a 'deterrent effect' on climate action.

title: Macron can't run in 2027, but he is hinting at a return in 2032
subhead: At a rally of his party's young members, Macron called on them to support him for the next 10 years. But he risks weakening his allies in the 2027 presidential election, in which he cannot run.
byline: By Mariama Darame and Nathalie Segaunes

title: Young African cycling hopefuls train in Brittany during Tour de France 2025
subhead: A group of promising cyclists have settled in a former farmhouse in the French village of Gomené as part of the International Cycling Union's Africa 2025 project, which aims to prepare for the Road World Championships in Rwanda in September.

title: In Srebrenica, 30 years after the genocide, the 'vicious circle' of denial continues
subhead: On July 11, Bosnia and Herzegovina commemorates the massacre of 8,000 Bosniaks by the forces of Serb General Ratko Mladic. Yet in a country still divided between Muslim Bosniaks, Catholic Croats and Orthodox Serbs, the work of remembrance remains far from unanimous.
byline: By Jean-Baptiste Chastand (Srebrenica [Bosnia and Herzegovina], special correspondent)

title: Nan Goldin confronts Arles photo festival audience about Gaza war: '75,000 Palestinians have been killed'
subhead: The American photographer and winner of the Women in Motion award took advantage of Tuesday's opening night, alongside writer Edouard Louis, to project images of the Palestinian territory ravaged by the Israeli conflict and call for action.

title: In Tunisia, migrants are driven out and their defenders prosecuted
subhead: '2015-2025: Europe's migration crisis' (5/5). For the past two years, the administration of Tunisian President Kais Saied, funded by the European Union, has been pushing sub-Saharan Africans far from cities, sometimes violently, and cracking down on any person or non-profit organization that supports them.
byline: By Julia Pascual (Tunis and Sfax (Tunisia), special correspondent) and Samuel Gratacap (Photos)

title: Is the post-coital moment always a sad one?
subhead: Studies have shed light on 'post-coital dysphoria,' which can affect women and – even more frequently – men after sexual intercourse. This condition may manifest in the form of anxiety, sadness or even irritability.
